div.head: Freedom in the District
div.summary: Echoes the answer given by the Washington National Republican and the Press to those who have denounced the abolition of slavery in the District of Columbia. Reprints several paragraphs from a petition submitted to Congress in 1828 by residents of the District asking that a scheme for gradual emancipation be implemented.

div.head: Parson Brownlow at the Methodist Book Concern, Cincinnati
div.summary: Summarizes Parson Brownlow's speech, in which he outlined the position and actions of the clergy in the South that he had encountered. The parson stated that most of them were secessionists, and that the few who were not could do little more than denounce secession, or they would be hung, regardless of their age.

div.head: The Movements at Yorktown
div.excerpt: "It is evident that all the appliances of modern warfare will be called into requisition, and, if the battle soon expected occurs, it will probably prove one of the most desperate that has ever taken place in any age or country."
div.summary: Predicts that the next great battle of the war will take place at Yorktown, and that if the Union forces are able to defeat a Southern force that appears to be well prepared and well led, the victory would be of the utmost importance for the North.

div.head: Memorial from the Colored People
div.summary: Reports that the African-American people of Washington have presented a memorial to Congress in which they express their gratitude for the recent action by which they were able to secure their freedom. In the memorial, however, they also requested a place to which they might emigrate and suggested Central America for the purpose.

div.head: Prisoner Shot at the Old Capitol Prison
div.summary: Relates that a prisoner who refused to follow an order to remove his head from his window was shot by a guard at the Old Capitol Prison in Hagerstown.

div.head: The Junior Indignant
div.excerpt: "Indeed, teachers should caution their intelligent pupils to beware of the error abounding Spirit, for a too frequent perusal of it might vitiate their English, in which they are striving to become proficient, as well as their morals."
div.summary: Berates the Valley Spirit for its grammatical and typographical errors and suggests that they employ "more experienced writers."

div.head: Another Disloyal Democrat
div.summary: Reports that the committee investigating the alleged disloyalty of Senator Starke from Oregon has determined that he offered support to the Confederacy and therefore was indeed disloyal to the government of the United States.

div.head: The True Reason
div.excerpt: "Slavery has grown powerful, defiant, domineering and dictatorial, and because it cannot rule the Republic for its own interest, it seeks to sink both it and freedom in a common ruin."
div.summary: Refutes the claim made by the Valley Spirit that it is the existence of abolitionists and not of slavery that is to blame for the war. Argues that the Spirit is not condemning the crime but the attempt to get rid of the crime as the evil.

div.head: The Spirit and the Workingmen
div.summary: Points out that the Valley Spirit has attempted to deny the Dispatch's charge that by ridiculing what the Spirit calls "small politicians" it has "sneered" at the workingmen of Chambersburg. The Dispatch again defends the artisans of the town from ill treatment in the press by the Spirit.

div.head: From Memphis
div.summary: Reports that the South still claims the battle at Pittsburg Landing as a victory, allegedly because more Union men were killed, wounded, or taken prisoner than were Confederate men.

page.pageNote: Advertisements for political candidates, column 1; news of a skirmish on Wilmington Island, news from General Bank's column that all is calm, official dispatch from General Banks, news of the continuing bombardment of Fort Wright, column 3; report that Governor Harvey of Wisconsin has drowned, that Fort Pillow has not been fired on in three days, and that a shipment of cotton and tobacco from the Tennessee River arrived in Pittsburgh, column 4; news of a murder in York County and other brief items and advertisements, column 5

div.head: Maj. George Stetzel
div.excerpt: "He looks remarkable well, and reports the boys in good health, fine spirits and anxious to be led against the enemies of their country and of freedom."
div.summary: Reports that Major George Stetzel, of Harlan's Pennsylvania Cavalry, visited friends in Chambersburg a few days prior.

div.head: Died from Wounds
div.summary: Reports that a member of Captain Wishart's Company who comes from Fulton County died from wounds received at the battle of Pittsburg Landing. His name was not given.

div.head: Death of a Soldier
div.summary: Reports that John Essom, a young man from Chambersburg whose parents live on East Queen street, died of chronic diarrhea in the hospital at Nashville, Tennessee, on March 29. He was about 24 years of age and was a member of Company A of the 77th Pennsylvania.

div.head: Contrabands
div.summary: Reports that several escaped slaves arrived in Chambersburg the previous Tuesday morning and have been "loitering" around town since. The Dispatch remarks that the fugitives should maintain "eternal vigilance" while there are still Breckinridge Democrats in town.

div.head: Promotion
div.summary: Announces that Lieutenant Thomas of Chambersburg, who has been recruiting for Company A of the 77th Pennsylvania, was promoted to Captain of Company H of the same regiment. Like all other recruiters, Captain Thomas has been ordered to rejoin his comrades in the field.

div.head: The Game Laws
div.summary: Reminds readers that it is unlawful to kill bluebirds, swallow, robins, or any other birds that eat insects, at any season. Points out that the killing of these birds has brought the destruction of fruit trees by insects.

div.head: A Young Horse Thief
div.summary: Relates that a boy of about fourteen, calling himself James Stout, was looking for a place to live and was taken in by Mr. F. Walk of Guilford township. Soon after taking up residence with Mr. Walk, the boy was caught attempting to steal a horse from Mr. Groosman, while the latter was attending church. The boy is now in prison.

div.head: Cut Worms
div.summary: Recommends a remedy for the cut worm, which destroys corn crops.

div.head: Marriages
div.summary: Mr. Peter Nicklas and Miss Margaret Henneberger, both of Chambersburg, were married on April 15.

div.head: Marriages
div.summary: Mr. Samuel Henneberger and Miss Mary E. Nicklas, both of Chambersburg, were married at the same time and place--April 15 in Chambersburg--as Mr. Peter Nicklas and Miss Margaret Henneberger.

div.head: Deaths
div.summary: John Henry, aged 5 years and 6 months, died of catarrh in Hamilton township on April 19. He was the son of David and Maria Henry.
